text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Added new IRM 8.7.16.1, Program Scope and Objectives, and related sections containing internal control information required by IRM 1.11.2.2.5, Address Management and Internal Controls. Incorporated information from old IRM 8.7.16.1, Introduction to Employment Tax Cases in Appeals, and IRM 8.7.16.2, Employment Tax Return Forms and Dates, into new, Program Scope and Objectives, and its related sections.

Revised various IRM sections to incorporate the contents of Interim Guidance Memorandum AP-08-1119-0014, Reissuance of Employment Tax Procedures for IRC 7436 Wage Issues, which issued on November 26, 2019.
Added new IRM 8.7.16.2, Using Issue Management System (IMS), requiring Appeals’ IMS use for providing Compliance with feedback on Appeals’ employment tax case determinations.

Incorporated information covered in old IRM 8.7.16.3 and IRM 8.7.16.4 (and related sections) into new IRM 8.7.16.3, Appeals Technical Employee (ATE) Receipt of Newly Assigned Case, and new IRM 8.7.16.3.1, Verifying the Statutory Period of Limitations. Changed the time frame for verifying statute from 5 workdays to 45 calendar days and eliminated references to Form 872-I and Form 872-IA (now obsolete). Distinguished the start of the ASED for an individual’s 1040 Additional Medicare Tax from the start of the ASED for Social Security and Medicare Taxes.
and reorganized IRM 8.7.16.5, and related sections on Settling an Employment Tax Case, 530 Relief, and CSP Offers. In addition, updated the address for routing CSP agreements.

Identiﬁed the transmittal and closing letters (for agreed and unagreed closures) along with the closing agreements used by Appeals for employment tax cases and revised information about the Form 2504 type agreement forms.
IRM 8.7.16.17, Coordinating Employment Tax with Social Security Administration (SSA), changed of the Associate Chief Counsel (CC:TEGE)” to “Office of Division Counsel (CC:TEGEDC).”
Added to IRM 8.7.16.19, Railroad Retirement Tax on Tip Income, a reference to IRM 11.3.29.4, Administration of the Railroad Retirement Act - Railroad Retirement Board.
Changed Exhibit 8.7.16-1 title from “Form 941-Employment Tax Examination Changes”, to “Sample Form 3610 for Form 941 Employment Tax Examination Changes” and revised sample tax periods.

) Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies without litigation on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer, a consistent application and interpretation of, and voluntary compliance with the Federal tax laws, and enhances public conﬁdence in the integrity and ciency of the Service. (1) Use of the Issue Management System (IMS) is mandatory for providing pliance with feedback on Appeals’ employment tax liability case decisions by Issue uploading the settlement determination documents (e.g. Form 5402, Appeals System Case Memorandum, computations, agreements, etc.) on the IMS system. Appeals employees who work these cases will have “read” and “print” through the IMS Team Website for cases in Appeals’ inventory. If the case is not in IMS, Appeals will follow the current Feedback Loop process. ACDS remains the Appeals system of record for case management and recording time spent on cases. Guide to Gaining & Modifying Access to IMS for a guide to gaining & modifying access to IMS. Verify the case is in IMS. If the case is not in IMS, ask your ATM to search the Account and Processing Support (APS) inventory in IMS for cases not currently in your Appeals IMS case inventory.

The primary role of the APS employee in IMS is to assign a case to the Appeals Team Manager, re-assign a case, and (when necessary) re-open a closed case. The APS user has permissions to view Appeals cases to be assigned, open (currently assigned), and closed on the web portal.
Appeals Team Manager

The primary role of the Appeals Team Manager (ATM) and Appeals Team Case Leader Team Manager (ATCLTM) in IMS is to manage and assign LB&I and SB/SE cases, including viewing IMS case documents, assigning Team Lead role, Appeals documents into IMS, and closing an Appeals case in IMS.
(4) Appeals Team Leader

The Team Leader role can be assigned to anyone who supports the resolution of an LB&I or SB/SE case. The primary functions of the Team Leader in IMS includes viewing and downloading case documents, building the team, and uploading Appeals documents.
(5) Appeals Team Member

The Team Member role can be assigned to anyone who supports the resolution of an LB&I or SB/SE case. The primary functions of the Team Leader in IMS includes viewing and downloading case documents, collaborating with the Team Leader and Team Members, and uploading Appeals documents when authorized by the Team Leader.

Section

is a safe harbor provision that prevents the Internal Revenue Service from retroactively and prospectively reclassifying a taxpayer’s workers from “non-employee” (e.g. independent contractor) to “employee” subject to federal employment taxes. Where there are controversies involving whether individuals are employees for purposes of employment taxes, Section
of the Revenue Act of
[P.L. No.
Stat.

)] provides employers (and not the workers) with relief from federal employment tax obli- gations if certain requirements are met. This relief provision applies to employment tax liabilities under Internal Revenue Code Subtitle C:
• Chapter
- Federal Insurance Contributions Act [FICA] • Chapter
- Railroad Retirement Tax Act [RRTA] • Chapter
- Federal Unemployment Tax Act [FUTA] • Chapter
- Collection of Income Tax at Source for wages [Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW)] • Chapter
- General Provisions Relating to Employment Taxes and Collection of Income Taxes at Source
• Chapter
- Railroad Retirement Tax Act [RRTA] • Chapter
- Federal Unemployment Tax Act [FUTA] • Chapter
- Collection of Income Tax at Source for wages [Federal Income Tax Withholding (FITW)] • Chapter

- General Provisions Relating to Employment Taxes and Collection of Income Taxes at Source If for purposes of employment taxes, the taxpayer did not treat an individual an employee for the period(s) in question and if all Federal tax returns (including information returns) required to be ﬁled by the taxpayer with respect to such individual for such period are ﬁled on a basis consistent with the tax- payer’s treatment of such individual as not being an employee, then for purposes of applying such taxes for such period with respect to the taxpayer, the individual shall be “deemed not to be an employee” unless the taxpayer had no reasonable basis for not treating such individual as an employee. A method for satisfying the “reasonable basis” requirement for not treating an individual as an employee for a period will be met if the taxpayer’s treatment for such period was in reasonable reliance on any of the following “safe harbors”:

a. Judicial precedent, published rulings, technical advice with respect to the taxpayer, or a letter ruling to the taxpayer; b. A past Internal Revenue Service audit of the taxpayer in which there was no assessment attributable to the treatment (for employment tax purposes) of the individuals holding positions “substantially similar” to the position held by this individual; or c. Long
standing recognized practice of a signiﬁcant segment of the industry in which such individual was engaged.

A taxpayer that fails to meet any of the three “safe havens” may still be entitled to relief if the taxpayer can demonstrate reliance on some other sonable basis for not treating a worker as an employee. See IRM 4.23.5.3.3.7, Other Reasonable Basis.

If the taxpayer timely ﬁled Form 1099’s, but fails the “substantive consistency” test or does not have a “reasonable basis”, the CSP offer provides that the taxpayer “begins to treat the workers correctly” and agrees to an assessment equal to one year’s tax for the latest audit year, computed using IRC 3509(a) rates, if applicable.
(3) 25% CSP Offer

If the taxpayer timely ﬁled Form 1099’s and has both a “substantive consistency” argument and a “reasonable basis” argument with some merit, the CSP offer must require future compliance and agreement to an assessment equal to 25% of the FICA tax and federal income tax withholding for the latest audit year, computed using IRC 3509(a) rates, if applicable. FUTA is assessed at 100%.

IRC 3402(d), Tax Paid by Recipient, provides that when an employer fails to withhold “Income Tax” from employees’ wages, the employer is liable for payment of the tax “required to be withheld”, unless the employer can show that the tax “not

withheld, as required” has been paid by the employee. Enter on Line 12 the “maximum amount of tax available for abatement under IRC 3402(d)” and attach to Form 4668 a schedule listing the workers and related income tax withholding amounts available for abatement that reconciles to the totals on Line 12. See IRM 8.7.16.12, Forms 4669 and 4670, for information on the process for the taxpayer (payor) to request this type of abatement.
Caution: If an employment tax assessment is made using IRC 3509(a) or (b) rates, a taxpayer will not be entitled to an abatement under IRC 3402(d). See IRM 8.7.16.6.1.4.1 (4).

IRC 3102(f)(3), Special Rules for Additional Tax, provides that when an employer fails to withhold “Additional Medicare Tax” from employees’ wages, the employer is liable for payment of the tax required to be withheld, unless the employer can that the tax “not withheld, as required” has been paid by the employee. Enter on Line 13 the “maximum amount of tax available for abatement under IRC and attach to Form 4668 a schedule listing the workers and related Additional Medicare Tax amounts “not withheld, as required” that reconciles to the totals on Line 13. See IRM 8.7.16.12, Forms 4669 and 4670, for information on the process for the taxpayer (payor) to request this type of abatement.

) IRC
allows employers to report and pay additional liability for tax and withheld income taxes as an interest-free adjustment, if certain ments are met. The regulations under IRC

provide that to be interest- free, the adjustment must be made by the due date of the return for the return period in which the error is ascertained and the amount of the underpayment must be paid by the time the adjusted return (e.g., Form

-X ) is ﬁled or interest will accrue from that date. An interest-free adjustment cannot be made for any Income Tax or Additional Medicare Tax withheld in a prior calendar - unless it is to correct an administrative error, IRC
applies, or the adjust- ment is reported on a Form
type agreement or other prescribed form. (

) The discovery date is when the employer has sufficient knowledge of the error to be able to correct it. Such knowledge may be obtained, for example, the course of an examination. In an agreed case, this is when the employer signs a Form
type agreement. For a protested case, it is at the conclu- sion of an Appeals conference. See Rev. Rul.
, I.R.B

) If an agreement is reached in Appeals, the taxpayer (if eligible) receives complete interest-free treatment for the FICA and federal income tax withhold- ing liability when full paid by the time Appeals receives the signed Form
type agreement. If Appeals receives a signed Form
-type agreement and the taxpayer doesn’t pay, interest starts the day after the date the agreement received.

IRC 6205 allows employers to report and pay additional liability for tax and withheld income taxes as an interest-free adjustment, if certain ments are met. The regulations under IRC 6205 provide that to be interest- free, the adjustment must be made by the due date of the return for the return period in which the error is ascertained and the amount of the underpayment must be paid by the time the adjusted return (e.g., Form 941-X ) is ﬁled or interest will accrue from that date. An interest-free adjustment cannot be made for any Income Tax or Additional Medicare Tax withheld in a prior calendar - unless it is to correct an administrative error, IRC 3509 applies, or the adjust- ment is reported on a Form 2504 type agreement or other prescribed form.
